source: [doctor] kayla ward, date of birth 4/28/2007, mrn 384920. she is here for a new visit with her mother for acne located on the face which started about 2 years ago and is present most every day. she has been using perc gel and washing regularly which is somewhat helpful. there are no associated symptoms including itching, bleeding, or pain. no additional past medical history. she lives with her parents and sister. they have a dog, bird and bonnies. she is in seventh grade. she plays basketball, volleyball and tap. she wears sunscreen in the summer. spf 30. no additional family history. hi kayla, i'm dr. juan price. i hear you are starting to get some acne on the face. how about the chest and back? [doctor] yes. what do you do for your acne in the morning and then what do you do at nighttime? i wash my face more like i wipe it down in the morning then at night i use an l facial cleanser called the superclarity cleanser. i finish with a toner and then the person gel. when you say wipe your face in the morning, do you use a product or just water? [patient] hmmm just water and a wash cloth really, if i feel really greasy, sometimes i'll use the elf cleanser in the morning too. [doctor] okay and is today a good day, bad day or an average day for you? [patient] hmmm i would say it's probably a good day for me of course since i'm here right? [doctor] acne is always good when you come to see the doctor. do you find that your acne flares with your periods? [patient] no, not really. [doctor] and do you get a regular period? [patient] yep. [doctor] how long have you been getting a regular period? [patient] hmmm i think about 2 years. [doctor] okay. the biggest flare probably was when she started school sports in the fall just with all the sweating. yeah, i'll do it. is there anything else that you've noticed, mrs. ward? [patient] no, kayla really has been doing a good job with the facial care regimen. it just doesn't seem to help as much as we wanted. [doctor] got it. okay. well, let's take a look then. full exam is performed today except for under the underwear and under the bra multiple benign navy on the trunk and extremities scattered skin colored papules open and closed comedones and erythematous papules on the face primarily on the forehead and with also some on the central cheeks and chin. the chest and back are relatively spared. and the remainder of the examination is normal. so what i'm seeing from your exam today is mild to moderate acne, mostly comedonal with small inflammatory component. [patient] okay, so is there anything we can do to help it? [doctor] yes, i would like to start with a topical therapy first. every morning you will wash your face with a mild cleanser. then use a moisturizer label noncommittogenic with sunscreen, spf 30 or higher. this means it won't clog your pors. now in the evening, wash your face with the same cleanser and allow it to dry. apply adapalene 0.1 % cream in a thin layer to the areas you generally get acne. i want you to start off using this a few nights a week and slowly work up to using it every night. if it, it is, excuse me, if it is very expensive or not covered by insurance, you can try differin gel over the counter. you can follow that with clean and clear bursa gel and a thin layer where you generally get acne and then a noncommunogenic moisturizer. your topical retinoid won't cause sun sensitivity so you will need to wear sunscreen when you are outside. it may also cause some dryness or irritation. [patient] okay. i can do that. [doctor] you also have multiple benign moles on your arms, legs, back, and abdomen. this means they all look normal with no worrisome features. we will see if you have any progress over the next 6 months and follow up at that time. [patient] okay. that sounds good. thank you. [doctor] do you have any questions for me? [patient] no, i don't think

[patient] well, i've always at the gym and lifted weights. i've been trying to keep with my routine of 2 days a week, but it's been hard. the pain is worse when i lift and i haven't been able to lift more than 15 or 20 pounds, which is very frustrating. [patient] not too much. i have iced a bit, but i have not taken anything for the pain. stopping the exercise and some ice has helped a bit, but it still hurts enough for me to come to see you. [patient] you're experiencing pain in your wrist because of your shoulder. we do see this type of issue when someone has a fall, so it's good you came to see us, he came in to see us so we could help. so what are the possible treatments? [doctor] well, we have a few options you can try. first option would be to start with physical therapy. i would recommend two sessions per week as well as any other exercises they give, [patient] you to do at home we can start if that doesn't improve your pain then we could try a cortisone injection. [doctor] i like the idea of starting with the physical therapy and have a next step if it doesn't help. i am not opposed to a shot, but would like to try the therapy first. alright, great. i'll get a referral ordered and they will call you within the next day or two to get you scheduled. [patient] okay. [doctor] mm-hmm also please continue to ice especially your shoulder and rest as much as you can. [patient] okay, i will. [doctor] give us a call or email if you have symptoms worsen, if your symptoms worsen or do not improve with the therapy. [patient] will do. thank you. i appreciate your help. [doctor] you're welcome. have a great day. [patient] you
